qas.question: What color did the Romans attribute to Venus, the goddess of gardens, vegetables, and vineyards?
What pigment was made by soaking copper plates in fermenting wine?
How many different words for the varieties of green exist in Latin?
Glass was soaked in what to make green?
When did Romans begin making the pigment verdigris?

plausible_answers.text: Pompeii, Herculaneum, Lyon, Vaison-la-Romaine, and other Roman cities

qas.question: What Roman cities hosted Venus' gardens?
How many words does Latin have for painting?
What did the Romans stop using green for in 2nd century AD?

context: The Romans had a greater appreciation for the color <a0_0>green<a0_0/>; it was the color of Venus, the goddess of gardens, vegetables and vineyards.The Romans made a fine green earth pigment, which was widely used in the wall paintings of <b5_0>Pompeii, Herculaneum, Lyon, Vaison-la-Romaine, and other Roman cities<b5_0/>. They also used the pigment <a1_0>verdigris<a1_0/>, made by soaking copper plates in fermenting <b3_0>wine<b3_0/>. By the <b4_0>Second Century AD<b4_0/>, the Romans were using green in <b7_0>paintings, mosaics and glass<b7_0/>, and there were <a2_0><b6_0>ten<b6_0/><a2_0/> different words in Latin for varieties of green.
